name: Baseball  For Dummies?  You Judge Online Quiz | Sports | 10 Questions

questions.text: I was 20 years old when I won my first batting title, but it was not in the Major Leagues.  I won six more before I crossed the Pacific Ocean to play with the Mariners in 2001.  In 2001, I was the American League Rookie of the Year and the season MVP Award winner.  I was the first ever Japanese postion player in the Majors.  Who am I?
questions.explanation:
Ichiro Suzuki.

	Ichiro played for the Orix Blue Wave in the Japanese baseball league from 1992-2000.  In his first three seasons in the Majors, he also was a Gold Glove winner.  In 2004, still with Seattle, Ichiro made a drive to surpass the hits record in a season which was set 80 years earlier.  The record was set by George Sisler in 1920 with the St. Louis Browns, who smacked 257 in the season.

questions.text: My first 10 seasons were split between the Mariners and the Rangers.  My 11th season found me in New York Yankee uniform.  As I was a shortstop, I moved to third base for the sake of the team, and gave way to teammate Derek Jeter.  In six of my first 10 seasons, I was in the top ten of the MVP voting.  I also hit over 50 home runs in 2001 and 2002.  Who am I?
questions.explanation:
Alex Rodriguez.

	After being the 2003 American League MVP with the Rangers, he left for the pinstripes in 2004.  He changed his jersey number from 3 to 13 for the 2004 season.  In his first 10 seasons in the Majors, Rodriguez hit 345 home runs.

questions.text: In 1947, I hit the first pinch-hit home run in World Series history.  That season was my second in the big leagues.  I was a back-up catcher to Aaron Robinson, but took over for the catching duties for the Yankees full time in 1949.  I set a record for career home runs by a catcher, hitting 358.  I was the American League MVP in 1951, 1954, and 1955.  When I retired in 1965, I had gone to 14 World Series, all with the Yankees.  My entire career of 19 seasons was with the Yankees, except for four games as a New York Met.  I later became a manager.  Who am I?
questions.explanation:
Yogi Berra.

	The others listed never played catcher, never played for the Yankees, and never went to a World Series.  Yogi had 12 World Series home runs to his credit.  He later as a manager, took the Yankees to the 1964 World Series, and then the Mets in 1973, losing both times.  He was an easy 1972 Hall of Fame inductee.

questions.text: Like the great Sandy Koufax, it took a few seasons before I came around in the Majors.  Also like Koufax, I pitched a perfect game, the 18th thrown in the history of the Major Leagues.  In 2002, I won my fifth Cy Young Award, pitching for Arizona.  Who am I?
questions.explanation:
Randy Johnson.

	Johnson won his first Cy as a Mariner in 1995, his eighth season, going 18-2.  Four consecutive Cy's were won as a Diamondback from 1999-2002, including the Triple Crown in 2002.  The former USC star was drafted by Montreal in the second round of the 1985 draft.

questions.text: Like NBA star, Latrell Sprewell, I had one incident that unfortunately overshadowed my great career.  The incident was that I hit Dodger catcher, John Roseboro, in the head with a bat.  For the San Francisco Giants, I won 20 games in a season six times in the 1960s.  With my high-kick delivery, I had the nickname, 'Dominican Dandy', and ironically, retired as a Dodger in 1975.  Who am I?
questions.explanation:
Juan Marichal.

	Although all pitchers, the others never played for the Giants or Dodgers.  Marichal was one of many Dominican players who played for the Giants in the 1960s, including Orlando Cepeda.  In that era, Marichal was much overlooked by Sandy Koufax of the Dodgers and Bob Gibson of the Cardinals.  He retired with a career record of 243-142 after 16 seasons.  Sprewell choked his coach during a practice session with his team.

questions.text: In a world class run from 1926-1958, these 33 seasons of Major League baseball saw which team go to 21 World Series?
questions.explanation:
New York Yankees.

	Since the emergence of Babe Ruth to the Yankees in 1920, they saw their first World Series crown in 1923.  An indicator of things to come, they saw the World Series in 1926, but were defeated by the Cardinals, four games to three.  From there, it was the Major League against the Yankees.  In these 21 World Series appearances, the pinstripes skunked the opposition six times, defeating the National League Champions, four games to none. These unfortunate skunked teams were:  1927 Pirates, 1928 Cardinals, the 1932 and 1938 Cubs, 1939 Cincinnati Reds, and the 1950 Phillies.  The Yankees finally got a taste of their own medicine, being skunked themselves in 1963, by the Los Angeles Dodgers.

questions.text: Babe Ruth hit 238 home runs in his first 10 seasons in the Majors.  I surpassed him by hitting 266 in my first 10 seasons.  I was the first right-handed batter to hit over 500 home runs, and the second hitter in history behind the Babe to reach 500.  In 1932, I led the Majors by hitting a forgotten 58 in the season.  Who am I?
questions.explanation:
Jimmie Foxx.

	The others were not born by 1932.  Foxx, began his career with the Philadelphia Athletics in 1925, then played for seven seasons with the Red Sox, beginning in 1936.  Ruth led the league for 12 seasons in home runs, while Foxx led the American League in four.  Foxx retired with 534 home runs.  He was a Hall of Fame inductee in 1951, after 20 seasons of baseball.  Nicknamed, "Double XX", he died in 1967, at the age of 59.

questions.text: Of all Yankee greats, if one took the jersey number of Babe Ruth, then added the jersey number of Lou Gehrig, then added the number of Yogi Berra, which Yankee player jersey would they come up with?
questions.explanation:
Thurman Munson.

	All Yankee greats in their time, only Munson wore the number 15.  Ruth (3), Gehrig (4), and Berra (8), totals Thurman's jersey number, which always stay in the hearts of Yankee and baseball fans.  Munson, a 11 season Yankee career player, catcher, and captain, died in mid-season 1979 in a plane crash.  It would take many seasons for baseball to get over this loss. After winning the American League Rookie of the Year Award, he also won the MVP in 1976.  Munson was very diversive to whatever the team needed, as he also played in the outfield, first base, designated hitter, and even played one game at third base. He died at the young age of 32.  The Yankees responded by winning the American League pennant the following season after his death.

questions.text: A new league was inducted in 1901, and played with the National League.  Both leagues were officially known as the "Major Leagues" for the rest of the 20th century.  Which league was it?
questions.explanation:
American League.

	The National Association existed from only 1871-1875.  The Union Association existed only in 1884.  Then, the American Association existed from 1882-1891.  The American League began with eight teams.  They were: Chicago White Sox, who won the first AL pennant, Boston Americans (later Red Sox), and the Detroit Tigers, who rounded out the top three. The other finishers were the Philadelphia (later Oakland) Athletics, the Baltimore Orioles (later NY Yankees), Washington Senators, Cleveland Blues (later Indians), and the Milwaukee Brewers (later St. Louis Browns and Baltimore Orioles.  Although being a part of the 'Major League', there was no World Series for another two seasons. In 1903, Boston (AL) defeated the National League Pittsburgh Pirates, five games to three.

questions.text: In 2004, who hit his 661st career home run, to surpass the great Willie Mays on the home run career list?
questions.explanation:
Barry Bonds.

	Bonds of the Giants who was Mays' godson, hit his 661st early in the 2004 season, being the number three player in history on the career home run list.  Bonds took a third seat to the great Babe Ruth (714) and Hank Aaron (755).
